results.title: The Choice is yours (Industrial safety)
results.creator_credit: Erika Hellfritsch, Colin Fox, John Ward, Ken Daley and Drayton Film Productions
results.brief_description: Considers the problems of industrial safety on civil engineering construction sites. Makes the point that it is not the obviously risky jobs and locations that cause the majority of accidents but simple carelessness. Reconstructs accidents, and stresses the value of goggles.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Erika Hellfritsch, Colin Fox, John Ward, Ken Daley and Drayton Film Productions

results.title: The Choice is yours
results.creator_credit: National Woman's Christian Temperance Union and Fred S Niemann
results.brief_description: Features Dr Andrew C. Ivy, Head of the University of Illinois Professional Schools in Chicago, and a young boy and girl questioning a chemistry teacher about alcohol. Through animation, the film shows physical effects of alcohol.

results.title: The Choice is yours
results.brief_description: Very explicitly the film explains the causes, symptoms, possible effects and treatment of gonorrhea and syphilis, and how it differs between men and women. Suggestions are made on precautions to take, and it is pointed out that unlike most other diseases the contracting of these is absolutely up to the individual and early VD can be cured quite simply.

results.title: The choice is yours
results.brief_description: Instructional film concerning water pollution and prevention. Appreciation for our water resources is stimulated first by tranquil scenes of nature as it was before the coming of man, then by exciting scenes featuring the many forms of water recreation man enjoys today. In stark contrast.. the diastrous effects of pollution. In the laboratories of a water resources commission the complexity of the problem is discussed and the procedures of water management agencies are described. The film ends with a dramatic abstract sequence where the choice between pure or polluted water is again presented, thus encouraging serious discussion of this vital part of our environment.

results.title: The Choice
results.creator_credit: Gordon Begg, Millbank Films and Imperial Chemical Industries
results.brief_description: Surveys the results of pollution by all kinds of waste products in the natural environment: air, water and land, and discusses the counter-measures and better disposal methods being used. Stresses the need for industry, commerce, individuals and the community to be prepared to take action.

results.title: The Choice
results.brief_description: The staff of a high school newspaper decide to do an issue on the drug problem, by dividing into two groups to research the pros and cons of drug taking. Projects the message that before a choice is made in favour of the non-medical use of drugs one should be fully aware of the dangers to mental and physical health inherent in such a choice. Intended mainly for school children. NOTE: Restricted to tertiary institutions, teaching hospitals, police and customs departments.

results.title: The Chinese girl = La Chinoise
results.creator_credit: De La Gueville, Anouchka Films, Parc Film and Jean-Luc Godard
results.brief_description: This experimental non-linear work, about five students who embrace Maoism, heralded the second wave of Godard’s filmmaking - The Revolutionary. Spending the summer in the bourgeois surrounds of a borrowed flat, the students become immersed in the doctrine of Chairman Mao’s Little Red Book, discussing methodologies (which include terrorism and assassination) to overthrow governmental systems. Heralded by some as groundbreaking cinema that subverted popular notions of filmmaking (recall Godard’s famous quote: “A story should have a beginning, a middle and an end, but not necessarily in that order”), “La Chinoise” also confounded many Godard admirers with its obscure polemic. Cast includes: Juliet Berto, Jean-Pierre Leaud, Anne Wiazemsky and Blandine Jeanson.

results.title: The China teapot story: a Chinese legend
results.creator_credit: Wladislaw Neherbecki and Sterling Educational Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Folktales from around the world”.
An animated story about a Chinese potter who makes a beautiful porcelain teapot for the Emperor who regards its worth as priceless. It is then seen to be desirable and is inevitably stolen from the Emperor’s palace. In a series of transactions that follow in various parts of the world, it is exchanged for items from other cultures that are equally regarded as priceless. Provides a simple introduction to the notion of trade, as well as the economic and aesthetic considerations involved in the determination of the worth of a product. Suitable for middle and upper primary level.

results.title: The Children of the mist
results.creator_credit: David H. Fowler, New Zealand National Film Unit and Conon Fraser
results.brief_description: Describes some of the problems of adjustment that the Maori and Polynesian islanders have, as they try to integrate into the European society of New Zealand, but still retain their tribal identity.

results.title: The Children of the city
results.creator_credit: Paul Rotha, Paul Rotha Productions and Budge Cooper
results.brief_description: This film illustrates how the Scottish Courts, under a recent Act of Parliament, treat the problems of juvenile delinquency, through the work of probation officers, child guidance clinics, and approved schools.
